title: New Book Tackles History and Legacy of Atomic Bomb
description: Garrett Graff, author of the new book The Devil Reached Toward the Sky: An Oral History of the Making and Unleashing of the Atomic Bomb, discussed the important lessons from the deployment of the atomic bomb as global tensions bring the world the closer to nuclear threats.  (Source: Bloomberg)

And one of the reasons I wanted to do this project right now for the 80th, as we mark sort of the passing of the last survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki is, I think it's worth remembering how terrible these weapons are and that it's up to us in our time to carry forward their life's mission that they are the last survivors of an atomic bomb.
summary: The author reflects on the increasing threat of nuclear proliferation in the United States, with India and Pakistan the two largest nuclear arsenals to ever come into conflict. This comes amidst ongoing disputes between the U.S. and Russia, which are engaged in a decade-long upgrade to the nuclear triad. The author suggests that over the next decade, we will likely see more countries joining the nuclear club than we have ever seen before due to rising geopolitical instability and concerns about America's commitment to international alliances. This could lead to more countries considering their own nuclear umbrella in order to secure peace with North Korea. The book also discusses the history of the Manhattan Project, which involved hundreds of thousands of Americans working on a project that dates back to the Reagan years.
shortSummary: The Manhattan Project's history and current tensions highlight the danger of nuclear proliferation, with rising tensions and global economic instability raising concerns over global nuclear security.
argos_summary: As we reflect on the 80th anniversary of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, concerns about nuclear proliferation are rising, with more countries potentially joining the nuclear club amid geopolitical instability. The Manhattan Project, often romanticized, involved extensive industrial efforts and the voices of countless workers, highlighting the duality of its legacy as both a triumph and a tragedy. The debate continues over the necessity of using atomic bombs in World War II, with differing perspectives among scientists and military personnel, raising questions about the implications of nuclear weapons in today's world.
